text: Ferrer says there's a high likelihood that the UK variant is in LA, but that it's unlikely that it's the dominant strain circulating here. The county's lab has tested 29 samples from people who have COVID here and it didn't show up so far, but it could as more samples are tested.

A bleak prediction:  "You and your loved ones are not invincible, you can get covid, you can get in a car accident," says Ghaly.

And if the surge continues or even worsens, when that happens, Ghaly says, "hospitals across the county may not be able to help you."
The county's cumulative COVID death toll is also close to 10,000, "the saddest milestone of all," Ferrer says.
LA County is reporting 13,661 new cases of the coronavirus today.

Ferrer warns that precautions taken before recent traveling were likely not enough to prevent new infections, like during Thanksgiving. 

"All it takes is one unfortunate encounter with an individual with covid-19 for you to become infected."

Solis sounds really worked up and says that people have been ignoring the orders and recommendations from officials for weeks and that has led to more than 6,900 people in the hospital in LA County with COVID. She warns that traveling last week could make things even worse.

On Christmas Eve, 148 people in LA County died of COVID, says supervisor Hilda Solis. We're averaging a death every 10 minutes.

"These are figures that can’t be normalized," she said. "Just like the sound of ambulance sirens, we can’t tune this out."

When it comes to cumulative rates of death, 93 of every 100,000 people in L.A. County have died of COVID-19, fewer than the 134 in Illinois, 121 in Arizona and 103 in Florida. If L.A. County were a state, it would rank about 28th in terms of death rate.

Within LA itself, division has emerged among officials regarding COVID policies. “As soon as there’s a sense that there’s not unity — that ... also creates a different kind of confusion and, in some cases, has given rise to a lot of defiance,” said Barbara Ferrer.

An analysis published in June in the Journal of the American Medical Assn. found that the odds of falling sick from the coronavirus were not significantly affected by the poverty rate or density of a person’s neighborhood but clearly increased as overcrowding increased.

Among the 25 biggest metro areas in the US, LA has the highest percentage of overcrowded homes -- perfect for the spread of the coronavirus. Eleven percent of LA homes are considered overcrowded, compared with about 6% in New York and the Bay Area. https://t.co/M3SXCrah9y
LA is uniquely vulnerable to a huge COVID surge. The popular image of L.A. — hillside mansions, urban sprawl and drivers cocooned in their cars — belies the gritty reality.

LA has become the latest epicenter of the pandemic in the United States. Our ICUs are full and the sound of sirens has become a constant. Deaths are mounting, and the situation is only expected to get worse.

I wrote about how we got here, with @ronlin :  https://t.co/M3SXCrah9y

The highest number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 in L.A. County during the summer surge was around 2,200.

Now it’s 6,800.

“We were planning to handle a lot, but we just didn’t see it going this far,” said LA County’s chief medical officer. “It’s heart-wrenching.”

The quick succession of holidays in the fall and winter months typically allows people to celebrate and spend time with loved ones in a brief period.

But that leaves little time for coronavirus cases to start falling before they spike again, creating surges on top of surges.

First the good news: in mid-December, COVID hospitalizations in LA were increasing each day by 5%. now it’s closer to 0.5%. 

the bad news: ICUs are already full so leveling off here is scary. and things could get way worse after Christmas 

our latest:

As outbreaks in other parts of the country have slowed, California's has picked up. Just a few weeks ago, California was generating 12% of the nation's new daily coronavirus cases. In late November, 8%. In late October, 5%.

California accounts for roughly 20% of the coronavirus cases being reported each day in the US, despite making up only about 12% of the nation's population. We're outperforming ourselves in the worst way.

“How many of us need to die for people to take this seriously?” said an LA nurse whose colleague died from COVID in May. “If we just keep dropping, who is going to take care of people?”

https://t.co/4kcxuIPIwz via @SamTLevin

Ferrer: “People mixing with others not in their household has driven the COVID-19 pandemic in L.A. County to the most dangerous levels that we have ever seen. The overwhelmed hospitals are the saddest proof of this reality.”

“We extend our deepest sympathies to the many families who are spending the holiday weekend grieving the loss of a loved one due to COVID-19, we wish you healing and peace,” said LA health director Barbara Ferrer.
There are currently 6,770 people with COVID in LA County’s hospitals. The most we saw over the summer was around 2,200.
LA County is reporting 29,464 new cases of COVID today, 15,538 from yesterday and 13,185 cases from today.
